ref.title: “Lines Written at the Lakes in Cumberland. | Derwentwater”

div.head: Title
div.p: “On Skiddaw and Derwent Water”.

A draft in the handmade pamphlet, MS II, is entitled “description of skiddaw & lake derwent”. In another handmade manuscript, “Battle of Waterloo, A Play, in Two Acts, with Other Small Poems, Dedicated to His Father” (now found tipped into MS V), a fair copy is entitled “On Skiddaw and Derwent Water” (see Manuscripts).

In the first published version, in the periodical, Spiritual Times, the original poem was split into two separate poems, each with a separate title, “Lines Written at the Lakes in Cumberland. | Derwentwater” and “On Skiddaw and Derwent-Water.”

Six decades later, unaware of this publication and working from the MS II version, Collingwood likewise split the poem into two, each with a separate title--respectively, “Skiddaw” and “Derwentwater”. In terms of content, Collingwood's two parts do not correspond with those in the Spiritual Times, as the “Lines Written at the Lakes in Cumberland” was drawn from the conclusion of the original draft, which is found in W. G. Collingwood's “Derwentwater”.

div.head: Genre
div.p: Topographical poem.

div.head: Manuscripts
div.p: MS II, “Battle of Waterloo, A Play, in Two Acts, with Other Small Poems, Dedicated to His Father”.

At some point between 1891 and 1893, the handmade booklet, “Battle of Waterloo, A Play, in Two Acts, with Other Small Poems, Dedicated to His Father”, was found, and by 1903 its separate leaves were tipped into blank pages remaining in MS V, an anthology of fair-copied verse that Ruskin entitled “Miscellaneous Poetry” but that, apart from the notebook's purpose, had nothing to do with this pamphlet.

div.head: Date
div.p: Composed between late February or early March and May 1829. The poem is misdated along with MS II as 1828, both by W. G. Collingwood in Poems [4o, 1891], 1:11-14, 262; Poems [8o, 1891], 1:11-14, 263, and by the editors of the Library Edition in Ruskin, Works, 2:536.

In his 10 May 1829 letter presenting the poem for his fatherʼs birthday, Ruskin says: “I think I began it about three months ago” (Ruskin Family Letters, 200)--that is, counting backwards from this letter, late February or early March (at the latest). This date corresponds convincingly to the draft poem's position in MS II, following “A Theme”.

Some revision of the poem for publication must have taken place between May and August 1829, when “Lines Written at the Lakes in Cumberland. | Derwentwater” was published; and further revision on the remainder of the poem could have taken place up until February 1830, when “On Skiddaw and Derwent-Water” was published.

div.head: Composition
div.p: The draft in MS II, “description of skiddaw & lake derwent”, was likely “that blank verse upon Lake Derwent” that Ruskin “demurred at bringing” to his father, as he recalled in a 10 May 1829 letter (not a posted letter, by any external evidence, but a cover letter inscribed on the outside, in Ruskin's hand, as “Birthday Odes | To my dear Papa"). On that occasion, Ruskin temporized because the poem “was designed for your birthday and I did not wish you to see it beforehand.” There was even “a line saying something about this happy day and I was afraid you would ask me what happy day and then the whole secret would gradually have been hauled out of my unwilling mouth” (Ruskin Family Letters, 199). The evasive maneuveur that Ruskin was recalling may have been occurred about April 1829, when a gap in the surviving family letters possibly indicates that John James was at home.

Such a line about a “happy day” is contained in the draft, MS II, at the end of first section, which describes Skiddaw (“. . . but no more on / on this sad subject on this happy day”). The line recurs in the fair-copy version, “On Skiddaw and Derwent Water”, which is found in “Battle of Waterloo, A Play, in Two Acts, with Other Small Poems, Dedicated to His Father”. On the occasion prior to John James's birthday, to which Ruskin refers, he apparently copied or recited a version that is not represented by extant copies, since Ruskin writes that he “found a way of evading this line as I found that when it was missed the poem sounded quite well without it” (Ruskin Family Letters, 200).

As Van Akin Burd remarks, “the poem 'Derwentwater,' which was apparently sent to [John James] as an enclosure with [Ruskin's 10 May 1829] letter is no longer with it” (Ruskin Family Letters, 200 n. 2). However, since Ruskin inscribed the letter as “Birthday Odes”--using the plural--the presentation copy may not have been devoted solely to the topographical poem. Rather, the enclosure may have been the handmade booklet, “Battle of Waterloo, A Play, in Two Acts, with Other Small Poems, Dedicated to His Father”, which contains the only surviving fair copy in Ruskin's hand. The description of the enclosure in Ruskin's letter matches this booklet more convincingly if one omits Burdʼs bracketed editorial insertion: “On Newyearsday I prepared a small poem for you,” and therefore “on your birthday it becomes me to have a much larger [one] for you” (Ruskin Family Letters, 199). That is, by a “larger,” Ruskin may have meant, not just a single larger poem, but a larger project--the handmade booklet, which he dated 1829, and which contains along with the poem several other poems and a play. The pamphlet also precisely meets the inscription on the letter, “Birthday Odes,” since it includes a fair copy of another 1829 birthday poem, “May”. Despite all this, one cannot discount the possibility that Ruskin's 10 May 1829 letter once accompanied a fair-copy version of the topographical poem, presently unknown, which perhaps was paired with the second 1829 birthday ode, “May”.

div.head: Revision and Publication
div.p: Ruskin's original poem was revised and split into two poems for publication in the Spiritual Times: A Monthly Magazine. Thus, Ruskin's first poem to appear in print, and his first publication of any kind, was “Lines”, which appeared in August 1829; and his second publication was “On Skiddaw and Derwent-Water”. The responsibility and authority for the splitting and revision of the poem are unknown. As the editors of the Library Edition speculate, the revision presumably was guided either by the magazine's editor, the Reverend Edward Andrews (1787–1841), or by Ruskin's father, John James Ruskin, or by both of them. Subsequent scholars have weighted the responsibility on the father's side (see, e.g., Maidment, “‘Only Print’”, 196), but in fact no evidence survives to document the process of revision.

Another mystery lies in the fact of the first publication repeatedly dropping out of view. Sometime in the late 1840s, John James Ruskin compiled a List of Published Poems, 1830-46 in blank pages remaining in MS IV, one of Ruskin's Red Books. The list, which John James presumably made in preparation for collecting his son's verse in the Poems by J.R. (1850), begins with the entry, “on Skiddaw & Derwent Water | page 72 Spiritual Times | Feby 1830 age 11 years,” omitting mention of the earlier “Lines” published in the August 1829 issue of the magazine. In the Poems (1891), W. G. Collingwood noted John James's listing of the 1830 poem in MS IV, but he ignored the clue in his editing even of the 1830 poem, basing his copytext on Ruskin's draft manuscript rather than on either of the printed versions. The recovery of the text of the printed poems--both “Lines”, and “On Skiddaw and Derwent-Water”--should be credited to the journalist and book collector, H. Robertson Nicoll (1851-1923), who in June 1895 published an article, “First Published Writings of Mr. Ruskin”, in a journal that he founded and edited, the Bookman. Yet no mention of this discovery was made by the editors of the editors of the Library Edition, who printed “On Skiddaw and Derwent-Water” based on copytext from the February 1830 Spiritual Times, heralding this version as “the earliest printed work of Ruskin,” while perpetuating the seemingly fatalistic neglect of the “Lines”. The complete facts about Ruskin's first publication had to be rediscovered by James S. Dearden, who corrected the record in a brief article, “John Ruskinʼs First Published Work”, published independently and almost exactly a century following the appearance of Nicoll's 1895 article.

a short-lived periodical edited by Ruskin's tutor, Edward Andrews (1787–1841). First, the concluding portion of the original poem was revised and published in the August 1829 issue as “Lines Written at the Lakes in Cumberland. | Derwentwater”. An explanation for the decision to concentrate on only these few lines may lie in the shortness of time available to the editor, from May 1829, when he is likely to have first read Ruskin's original poem, and August 1829, when the “Lines” appeared in print (see Discussion). Only a few months were available for revision of Ruskin's concluding lines, and for delivery of a brief but polished poem to the printer in time for the magazine's release in August.
A more leisurely space of time allowed for revision of the main body of Ruskin's poem and its publication in February 1830 as “On Skiddaw and Derwent-Water”.

Whoever was responsible, the “Lines” was formed by isolating the third strophe of the original poem, which in the MS II draft was designated by Ruskin as the “conclusion,” beginning “sweet derwent on thy winding shore.” (In the fair copy, contained in “Battle of Waterloo, A Play, in Two Acts, with Other Small Poems, Dedicated to His Father”, this concluding section is not subtitled, but it is marked by a horizontal bar above “Sweet Derwent on thy winding shore.”) In addition, a number of significant revisions were made to the now separated parts of the poem. Most obviously, “Lines” concludes with a moralizing couplet, which does not appear in the original; and decorous revisions transform the conclusion of “On Skiddaw and Derwent-Water”, as well.

The pious sentiment in these revisions may be viewed as alien to the original secular topographical poem, as found in the surviving 1829 draft and fair copy. The process of revision to bring about this change may be reflected in a debate over the respective claims of worldly beauty and religious austerity, which appears to be underway in fragments that, in MS II, occur amid draft of “Eudosia”--“These worldly things are fair and beauteous too”, and “We say that this world is unhappy”. The debate--if debate it is, and not two statements in a related apologia for this-worldly beauty--seems to culminate in MS II with another fragment, “If such the beauties of an earthly shore”, which is an almost illegible, scrawled draft that may represent Ruskinʼs attempts at revising the concluding portion of the poem on Skiddaw and Derwent for publication. If these fragments represent that revision process, they must date between 10 May 1829, when Ruskin wrote his letter presenting some form of the poem to his father, and August 1829 when “Lines” was published--not the year and more since 1828, when Collingwood believed that Ruskin first composed his topographical poem. Further revision on the remaining body of the poem could have taken place up until February 1830, when “On Skiddaw and Derwent-Water” was published.

W. G. Collingwood edited the poem using the MS II draft version as copytext (Poems [4o, 1891], 1:11-14; Poems [8o, 1891], 1:11-14). Apparently, by 1891 Collingwood had not seen the booklet, “Battle of Waterloo, A Play, in Two Acts, with Other Small Poems, Dedicated to His Father”, containing the fair copy, although he made up for the oversight in 1893 and mentioned both the “Waterloo” booklet and the poem in Life and Work of John Ruskin (1:37-38). Had Collingwood been aware of the fair-copy version in the “Waterloo” booklet, he surely would not have troubled to “decipher” his copytext from the “childish and almost illegible scribble” in MS II (Poems [4o, 1891], and Poems [8o, 1891], 1:11-14).

Collingwood did not lack knowledge of the Spiritual Times printed version of the poem. In his “Preliminary Note on the Original MSS. of the Poems,” Collingwood noted that MS IV contains the List of Published Poems, 1830-46 inscribed in this Red Book in the late 1840s by Ruskin's father; and he quotes the first entry in the list: “on Skiddaw & Derwent Water / page 72 Spiritual Times / Feby 1830 age 11 years” (Poems [4o, 1891], 1:262; Poems [8o, 1891], 1:264). Presumably, the scarce periodical was unavailable to Collingwood or even traceable; and unable to document the reference, he ignored the implication. Two years later, in his 1893 biography of Ruskin, Collingwood persisted in identifying Ruskin's first publication as the March 1834 prose piece, “Enquiries on the Causes of the Colour of the Water of the Rhine” for the Magazine of Natural History; and he stood by that account in the 1900 revised edition of the biography (Collingwood, Life and Work of John Ruskin, 1:57, and see vol. 1, app., p. iv; Collingwood, Life of John Ruskin, 41, 409).

Even if Collingwood had followed up on the clue in John James's List of Published Poems, 1830-46, he might not have been led to the August 1829 printing of “Lines Written at the Lakes in Cumberland. | Derwentwater”, since, surprisingly, John James does not mention it. Instead, whereas Collingwood, like the Reverend Andrews, divides the poem into two parts, the later editor did not observe the same division or use the titles as published in Spiritual Times. Rather, Collingwood was prompted to his division of the poem in part by an accidental feature of the MS II draft, in which the section that he separated out and entitled “Skiddaw” happens to be followed sequentially by the prose fragment, Sermon Notes ["christs intercession"]. In MS II, where the poem's draft resumes immediately following these sermon notes, there is no indication that Ruskin intended a separate poem called, as Collingwood entitles it, “Derwentwater.” The draft following the sermon notes begins “skiddaw derwent water / Now derwent water come a looking glass”--a transition of a like kind with one in the draft prior to the sermon notes, which Collingwood omitted from his printing of “Skiddaw”: “But enough / Ive treated of the clouds. now skiddaw come” (falling in lines 14-15, as printed in PJR, 1:11).

One silent omission in Collingwood's version comprises the penultimate half-line and the concluding line that referred to John James's birthday, a decision presumably in keeping with the policy that “Birthday Addresses usually need lopping to be presentable as ‘poems’” (Poems [4o, 1891], 1:11-14; Poems [8o, 1891], 1:11-14[1:270].)

With the recovery of “Battle of Waterloo, A Play, in Two Acts, with Other Small Poems, Dedicated to His Father”, the editors of the Library Edition were able to publish the fair-copy version of the poem, “On Skiddaw and Derwent Water”. As their main copytext, however, Cook and Wedderburn printed the February 1830 Spiritual Times version, “On Skiddaw and Derwent-Water”, which they heralded as “the earliest printed work of Ruskin”--the new editors presumably following up on the evidence that Collingwood had neglected or ignored in John James's List of Published Poems, 1830-46. Cook and Wedderburn drop the complete text of the fair-copy version from the “Waterloo” booklet into a note, and they treat Collingwood's version taken from the draft in MS II as presenting variants of the fair-copy “Waterloo” version (Ruskin, Works, 2:265-68).

Cook and Wedderburn did not print “Lines Written at the Lakes in Cumberland. | Derwentwater”, nor did they acknowledge any awareness that this earlier publication existed in the August 1829 Spiritual Times. Curiously, Cook and Wedderburn had even less excuse in overlooking the earlier publication than did Collingwood in neglecting the 1830 “On Skiddaw and Derwent-Water”, since the “Lines”, which is truly “the earliest printed work of Ruskin,” had already been discovered by the journalist and book collector, H. Robertson Nicoll (1851-1923). In June 1895, Nicoll published an article, “First Published Writings of Mr. Ruskin”, in a journal that he founded and edited, the Bookman, in which he discussed the Spiritual Times, and he reprinted the 1829 “Lines” along with the 1830 “On Skiddaw and Derwent-Water”. The neglect of Nicoll's discovery, or at least of the entirety of his discovery, led to the complete facts about Ruskin's first publication having to be rediscovered and published independently by James S. Dearden almost exactly a century after the appearance of Nicoll's article (Dearden, “John Ruskinʼs First Published Work”).

Cook and Wedderburn do not cite Nicoll's article anywhere in the Library Edition, although they quote from another article by him on Ruskin that was published in the same journal (Ruskin, Works, 38:381). Since both Cook and Wedderburn's bibliographical note (Ruskin, Works, 2:265 n.1) and Nicoll's article contain details about the Spiritual Times that are lacking in the other, it is possible that the two investigations were independent--or perhaps that Cook and Wedderburn, learning about Nicoll's discovery, but neglecting to track down his article, consulted a copy of Spiritual Times on their own, albeit imperfectly. On Nicoll's part, it seems equally ungrateful that his article neglects to cite Collingwood's “Preliminary Note on the Original MSS. of the Poems,” for apart from Collingwood's quotation from John James's # List of Published Poems, 1830-46, how otherwise could Nicoll have been led to the Spiritual Times? Whatever the editors' exchange or lack of one, it was apparently Nicoll who made the connection between the elusive magazine and Edward Andrews, the link that enabled him to find Ruskin's poems by seeking the help of the Andrews family: “I have before me a volume containing ten numbers, all that were published, of the Spiritual Times. . . . The editor was the Rev. Dr. Andrews, minister of Beresford Chapel, Walworth, one of the most distinguished dissenting ministers of his time. . . . The distinction of the periodical is that it contains the first published writings of Mr. Ruskin. Mr Ruskin, it will be remembered [from Praeterita], was at one time a pupil of Dr. Andrews, and was occasionally present in his chapel, where he remembers seeing Dr. Andrews's daughter [Emily Andrews, 1824-62], afterwards Mrs. Conventry Patmore. Through the kindness of Dr. Andrews's granddaughter, [the social activist] Miss Eliza Orme [1848-1937], I have been able to identify Mr. Ruskin's contributions” (“First Published Writings of Mr. Ruskin”).
E. T. Cook cobbled together yet another version from the February 1830 Spiritual Times and Collingwood's editing of MS II version (Cook, Life of John Ruskin, 23).
James S. Dearden printed the version found in “Battle of Waterloo, A Play, in Two Acts, with Other Small Poems, Dedicated to His Father” in Three Lakeland Poems.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: While a cachet belongs to a first published work, the circumstances supporting the publication in 1829-30 of “Lines Written at the Lakes in Cumberland. | Derwentwater” and “On Skiddaw and Derwent-Water” in 1829-30 cannot compare with those surrounding the publication in late 1834 of “Fragments from a Metrical Journal” (drawn from Account of a Tour on the Continent) and “Saltzburg”. These latter poems appeared in Friendshipʼs Offering, a widely disseminated and broadly popular literary and artistic annual, edited by a professional poet, Thomas Pringle (1789–1834). “Saltzburg” was even accompanied by a steel engraving of a vedute of the city drawn by a professional, albeit not a well known artist. Prior to these poems' publication, Ruskin's father took the auspicious step of consulting with a nationally celebrated author, James Hogg (ca. 1770–1835), about the probability of the youth's future success as a poet; and the editor, Pringle, squired the young Ruskin on a state visit to the doyen of London literary culture, Samuel Rogers (1763–1855). The occasion was carefully planned to bring Ruskin forward as the author who signed himself “J.R.,” whereas Ruskin's previous appearance in the Spiritual Times, while doubtless a source of great pride to the family, was not accompanied by such gravity and deliberation.

At the same time, the two occasions share the characteristic of being petted and wheedled into realization by family and friends. In 1834, the Ruskins had already gained a footing inside the publishing house responsible for Friendshipʼs Offering, Smith, Elder, which employed Ruskin's cousin, Charles Thomas Richardson (1811–34); and even John James's appeal for professional advice from Hogg was ventured on the strength of a personal connection--the Ettrick Shepherd's visit to Herne Hill two years earlier, an introduction probably arranged by Pringle. Underpinning these connections were the bonds uniting Scottish professionals who had come south to make their fortunes in the metropolis. In 1829, the personal connection leading to publication in the Spiritual Times was that the monthly magazine was edited by the Reverend Edward Andrews (1787–1841), Ruskinʼs tutor, and the family's clergyman at the Congregational chapel in Walworth.

The Ruskins engaged Andrews to tutor Ruskin starting in April 1829, only about five months prior to the publication of “Lines Written at the Lakes in Cumberland”, in August (Ruskin Family Letters, 200); and presumably Andrews would not have seen Ruskin's original poem prior to its presentation to John James on his 10 May birthday. Only a few months elapsed, therefore, between when Andrews likely first read the poem and when he oversaw its revision and printing. Thus, the shortness of time may account for the decision to isolate only the conclusion of the poem and present it as “Lines.” appears, published his own childrenʼs verse in the journalCoventry Patmoreʼs Angel, and so it was natural enough that he would edit verse by his precocious new student. (Reciprocally, John James would later copy verse by Andrewsʼs daughter Eliza in Ruskinʼs MS VI [see part 1, MS VI, e].) In retrospect, then, it was auspicious that, in Ruskinʼs May 10 birthday letter to his father accompanying the MS V “On Skiddaw and Derwent Water,” he devoted a quarter of the space celebrating the recent “coming of the tutor”--“a most important aera of my life” (RFL, 200). Worshiping Andrewsʼs mirthful yet learned character, Ruskin must have been ecstatic to be published in his tutorʼs magazine, whatever he may have felt about the revisions demanded of his poem.

The subsequent oversight of the 1829 printing of “Lines” cannot be attributed entirely to Cook and Wedderburnʼs carelessness. ; see part 1, MS IV). Although John James compiled this list in the later 1840s, almost two decades following the publication of “Lines,” it is very odd that the admiring father could have forgotten even the slightest detail about Ruskinʼs first appearance in print. Surely, John James would have recalled not only his own pride but also, if a now common belief can be credited, his part in revising the poem for press (see B. E. Maidment, “‘Only Print’--Ruskin and the Publishers,” Durham University Journal 63, no. 3 [n.s. 32, no. 3] [June 1971]: 196). (No copies, incidentally, of either the August 1829 or the February 1830 issues of the Spiritual Times are presently known to have been owned by the Ruskins--the Bembridge copies, one of the last additions to the collection prior to its move to Lancaster, having originally belonged to Andrews--but it is beyond credibility that the family did not own both issues. See RBB, 214; and James S. Dearden, “The Ruskin Galleries at Bembridge School, Isle of Wight,” Bulletin of the John Rylands Library 51, no. 2 [Spring 1969]: 334.) John Jamesʼs mistaken entry in MS IV is crossed out in pencil, which may mean that somebody in the family had spotted its inaccuracy; however, the scoring could also represent John Jamesʼs decision, a curious one, not to include his sonʼs first two publications in the 1850 Poems by “J.R”--not even the 1830 “On Skiddaw and Derwent-Water,” which he certainly remembered. The omission raises interesting questions that cannot be resolved in light of the available, largely negative evidence, but that at least challenge prevailing assumptions. Did John James, for example, in fact have a hand in revising the 1829/30 poems for press--a notion, after all, that started with a mere hazarded opinion by Cook and Wedderburn that “it is possible that Ruskinʼs father or the editor touched them up for publication” (Works, 2:265 n.)? Was there, rather, something in the editing of the poems, and Andrewsʼs role in their publication, that either John James or Ruskin himself disliked enough to exclude them, two decades later, from the private-circulation collection? In 1850, John James informed his son that “we shall not print your 12 year poems which the marvellous are better in your own printed written [i.e., hand-lettered] little Book--We shall begin with Months age 16 I believe unless you desire earlier pieces” (qtd. in “Ruskinʼs Poems 1850”). This does not explain why John James preferred the earlier poems to remain in their presentation-copy format; and, in any case, the 1850 Poems did not begin with “The Months” (no. 194) but with “Song” (no. 176), a previously unpublished poem of 1833. “Skiddaw” and “Lines” could have been vetoed by Ruskin owing to their trammelment in the religious and intellectual conflict already mentioned. John James could have harbored some resentment of Andrews as the first competition by an older male for his sonʼs affections, a possible jealousy that might have fed John Jamesʼs and Margaretʼs later list of reasons for disapproving of the preacher and his family (see RFL 242-43, 366). Again, one must guard against overinterpreting negative evidence, but the subsequent bibliographic history concerning Ruskinʼs first publications grows irresistibly bizarre. In a part of Deucalion issued in October 1879, Ruskin confidently relayed an anecdote that transferred the event of his first appearance in print to his first prose publication, his 1834 papers for Loudonʼs Magazine of Natural History (nos. 190-91, 193): I well yet remember my fatherʼs rushing up to the drawing-room at Herne Hill, with wet and flashing eyes, with the proof in his hand of the first sentences of his sonʼs writing ever set in type,--“Inquiries on the Causes of the Colour of the Water of the Rhone” . . . . My mother and I eagerly questioning the cause of his excitement,--“Itʼs--itʼs--only print!” said he. Alas! how much the “only” meant! (Works, 26:275) Ruskin may have been misled by a recent bibliography of his published writings, Shepherd, of which the first edition was published in September 1878, and which lists the “Inquiries” as Ruskinʼs first periodical publication. In October 1878, Ruskin had written to Shepherd of the bibliography, “It will be of extreme value to me in filling up what gaps I can in this patched coverlid of my life before it is draped over my coffin--if it may be” (Works, 34:537). Shepherd, however, must have been misled in his turn by Ruskin, who, in an 1872 edition of the Catalogue of the Rudimentary Series of drawings at the Oxford schools, had remarked “that Mr. Loudon was the first literary patron who sent words of mine to be actually set up in print, in his Magazine of Natural History, when I was sixteen” (Works, 21:243). The important point, I believe, is that Ruskin--in the 1870s and in the context of his writings on drawing, botany, and geology--wanted to believe that his first publications were scientific and factual, not poetic, in nature. Since Shepherd and Ruskinʼs published remarks in the 1870s on his first publication would have been taken as authoritative, the succeeding major bibliographies--Wise (1:302-3, 2:111), and the chronological list of publications appended to Collingwoodʼs Life (1893, 1:233)--likewise awarded the distinction to the 1834 papers for Loudonʼs Magazine. Ruskinʼs first poetry publications, according to these bibliographies, were the 1835 contributions to Friendshipʼs Offering (see nos. 180, 207; Wise, 2:123; Collingwood, Life [1893], 1:233). Wise and his co-editor Smart were unlikely to be disabused by Ruskin or the Severns of any errors, the response from Brantwood to Wise being as politely insouciant and unhelpful as Ruskin had been to Shepherd (“Wise and Ruskin I,” 48, 51-52). Collingwood, for his part, may have relied more on Wise and Smart than they did on him (see “Wise and Ruskin I,” 46-47). Collingwoodʼs persistence in the error is remarkable, however, since he knew about John Jamesʼs entry in MS IV on the Spiritual Times publication and even printed it, without comment, in 1891 (PJR 1:264; Collingwood misprinted the 1830 date of publication as “1831”). This did not prevent Collingwood two years later in the Life (1893) from maintaining that Ruskin “began his literary career” as the “analytic John Ruskin . . . already an enfant terrible” (1:49-50). In light of what, by the 1890s, appears to have settled into a prejudice favoring Ruskinʼs analytic and scientific beginnings, Cook and Wedderburn must be given credit for locating at least the 1830 Spiritual Times version of “On Skiddaw and Derwent-Water,” which they used as their main copytext. Still, this printing contains one-and-a-half dozen punctuation variants from the original Spiritual Times version and changes the wording of three lines (line 11, “Chasing the others off” for “Chasing each other off” in the original; line 17, “majestic, a giant-natureʼs work” for “majestic, giant-natureʼs work”; and line 42, “And when heʼs made it” for “And when heʼs made”). The “Lines” were not, as the published title claims, “written at the lakes in Cumberland.” Rather, as Cook and Wedderburn are probably correct in suggesting about “On Skiddaw and Derwent Water,” the poetry harkens back to the familyʼs 1826 trip to the Lakes (Works, 2:265 n. 1); they had also visited the district in 1824 and 1822 (TLC, 6-7). A “great tour” to the Lakes projected for 1828 had been cancelled due to the death of John Jamesʼs sister (see no. 25). Perhaps Ruskin believed that poetic compensation for the lost tour and anticipation of next journey to the Lakes (1830) would be appropriate for his fatherʼs 1829 birthday.

In fact, “description of skiddaw & lake derwent,” as Ruskin entitled the draft and the fair copy of his poem (MSS II, V), was composed between late February or early March and May 1829 for his fatherʼs birthday. Then, within a few months—not a few years, as always believed—a part of the “description” was published. That part became the “Lines Written at the Lakes in Cumberland” in the August 1829 Spiritual Times, a journal owned and edited by Ruskinʼs tutor, the Reverend Edward Andrews. In the following February, 1830, the remaining portion of the original “description” appeared as “On Skiddaw and Derwent Water.”
